title: Covid-19 Tools
description: In late February when the realization of a looming pandemic hit, I started building tools for our newsroom to help track the spread. | I built one of the first API's that scraped and aggregated multiple sources of data into a consistent format useful for ingestion into other apps and analysis programs.| Maps existed, but the lack of normalization for per capita rates meant that they were just population density maps that didn't tell the full story. So I built an interactive one that normalized confirmed rates and deaths per county by total and by last 48 hours. This helped our team get a better handle on what hotspots were occuring and where. | Testing data was available, but fragmented and not easily compared so I built a chart that helped visualize how and if the curve was flattening relative to any state and its surrounding states.

title: Interactive Crazy Wall
description: The crazy wall was an idea conceived by our design studio to combine research from multiple reporters and help visualize the flow of a Mexican cartel's infiltration into areas across the US. The problem is that the image is so large and so detailed that it simply cannot be shared online in it's full size. I wrote the processing script that slices this massive gigapixel image into tiles so that you can zoom and pan just like a map. I then wrote an app that allowed reporters to collaborate and place annotations on top of it in the form of markers to make it easier for the pubic to have some context about what they're looking at.

title: Matt Bevin Pardon Database
description: In the fall of 2019 former Kentucky governor Matt Bevin made a series of questionable pardons and commutations of convicted offenders. We were tipped off before the full list of the pardons were available on the Secretary of State's website. The first thing that I did was to write a program that parses and dumps the contents of the pardons into a shared spreadsheet as they became available. This spreadsheet was distributed among our newsroom for use on follow up and analysis in stories. I took the initiative to quickly build a public facing database to help enhance our coverage. The Courier Journal newsroom went on to win the Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Reporting for coverage of this story.

title: Election Results Analysis
description: Election analysis map is a quick turn template that I wrote during an election night. It can look at and compare counties and/or precincts to compare relative strength of a candidate compared to their rivals.

title: Election Results
description: Election results template is the frontend to a larger network of components that I developed called ELX. The results are streamed in on election night from the ELX backend which is scraping data from multiple sources and delivering the most recent version to the client. The results page is generic and can be bootstrapped entirely from a data file making it easily reusable across elections. While data is streamed, animations occur showing numbers counting up, bar charts easing, and the order of who's currently ahead in a race smoothly transitioning into place.

title: K-PREP Test Scores
description: Each year the KDE releases a data dump of performance metrics related to testing. I distill the primary information down into a searchable database.

title: Kentucky Jeopardy Quiz
description: This was a quick turnaround piece about Kentucky history that is built on a reusable quiz template.

title: Metro Council Tax Proposal
description: A controversial proposal to increase taxes on some types of insurance premiums in Louisville led to a split between metro council members. There was a lot of speculation at the time about how council members felt about this and so this was a quick turn interactive designed to show the state of sentiment at that time.

title: Austin Risin Series Landing Page
description: The Austin Rising series looks at a small town in Indiana and it's struggles to overcome one of the worst HIV outbreaks in the midwest. Using mockups and style guides from our design studio, I translated the print style into both a landing page as well responsive layouts for each individual article.

title: JCPS Elementary Suspension Lookup
description: This is a quick turn custom chart that shows how school suspensions in JCPS have been rising at an alarming rate.

title: Louisville Sewer Collapses
description: We requested data from MSD and mapped it in an attempt to show just how where sewer collapses were happing in the city. I also used GIS vector data from LOJIC and combined that with data of the sewer lines ages to build the magma styled overlay.

title: Kentucky License Quiz
description: A quick turn piece that presents a quiz as a flowchart to help users better understand how the new travel ID works in Kentucky.

title: MMA Investigation Landing Page
description: In 2017, lax regulations in the local MMA circuit contributed to the death of a contender. This quick scrollytelling piece was designed to be the intro to the main bar.

title: Abandoned Vehicle Complaints Map
description: Quick turnaround map to show the depth of abandoned vehicles in Louisville.

title: Kentucky Lynchings Map
description: In 2018 a memorial in Montgomery Alabama was unveiled to honor victims of lynching. We wanted to localize this story but after a back and forth with their poc we were not able to obtain any information about the individual victims included in the memorial. We decided to do the research ourselves. I started by writing a scraper for the University of Washingtons database on lynching and filtering out by Kentucky. We also did some research and clarified some of the narratives using our own archives. The result was an interactive map of known lynchings in Kentucky by county.

title: Kentucky Derby Headlines
description: Along the lines of 'This Day in History', I really wanted to build a quick turn visual piece that explores the evolution of the front page of the Courier Journal announcing the winner of the Derby through history. No data, just a trip down memory lane. This page uses a scraper that I built to interface with Newspapers.com non-public API to programatically pull the front page from a list of specified dates. The mapping library Leaflet is used to allow for smooth panning and zooming of the image so that users could read the full page.

title: Civil War Monument Map
description: In 2017 the removal of a handful of confederate monuments ignited a heated debate in the community. I decided to take a look at just how many civil war monuments existed in Kentucky. This was a surprisingly difficult task as there was no list at the time. I scraped the pdf's from the National Park Service registry of monuments then used satellite imagery to track down the exact location of each one.

title: Louisville's Underground Tunnels
description: This was a fun piece we did for Halloween in 2017. Our resident "creepy place" expert Tom Novelly took photographers through six different tunnels in Louisville while documenting their history. I designed and built the entire page implementing a Mapbox map along with photo galleries and videos.

title: Hurricane Map
description: After Hurrican Irma hit in 2017, we put together a list of the top 10 costliest hurricanes in the US recorded so far. Rather than just put it in a table, I decided to jazz it up a little with scroll driven map.

title: Solar Eclipse Locator Map
description: Because the path of the eclipse totality ran through Kentucky, I took the initiative to build a locator map complete with details on where the eclipse would be viewable and when. This site quickly went viral across the nation and broke newsroom Chartbeat records for having over 25k concurrent visitors at a time. To handle the load of unanticipated traffic, I quickly built a server side caching mechanism that took the load off of the geocoder and improved response times by 10x.

title: Voter Registration Quiz
description: In 2017 I built a private voter registration database using data from the SBoE in Kentucky. The intent was to use it alongside LexisNexis for research and verification purposes. But courts reporter Andrew Wolfson thought it would be interesting to create a quiz to see if people could guess the party affiliation of notable Louisvillians. As a social experiment, I captured all answers to the quiz (anonymously) in order to track what the overall sentiment was towards each person.

title: Air Quality Map
description: A quick turn locator map of air quality by neighborhood complete with address lookup.

title: Suboxone Map
description: Quick turnaround map and data list showing rogue suboxone clinics across Kentucky.

title: Explorer Abuse List
description: This was the visual component to our investigative piece on the Explorer Scout abuse cases across America. I was asked to do a simple map but wanted to take a different approach with the data we had. I didn't want a standard locator map where people could simply look up the handful of instances in their own city and ignore the rest. I wanted users to have to scroll through each and every case and narrative that had been uncovered so far. A subtle yet uncomfortable impression of just how long and widespread this abuse has been. While we didn't force users to go through this page to get to the main article, we clocked a very high engagment time on those who did.

title: This Day in History
description: This was a pet project of mine and probably one of my favorites that I ever worked on. Not just the end result, but the challenge in getting there. I'm a huge fan of the history of Kentucky and could spend hours at a time scanning through old newspapers. I thought it would be interesting if each day, after reading the current paper, I could also take a look back at one from the same day in a random year in the past. To do this I reverse engineered Newspapers.com non-public API in order to be able to programatically pull images from archived papers. I then set up a script that would automatically oad a new one from a random year every morning. The use of the Leaflet mapping library allows you to zoom and pan the image to help make it more readable.

title: Sewer Overflow Explainer
description: An interactive that explains how a combined sewer overflow works with a series of maps showing where they are located in Louisville.

title: Whiskeyrow Timeline
description: This was an experiment with using Mapbox GL to guide users on a path of the history of Whiskey Row.

title: It's Our Bridge
description: I did this interactive multimedia gallery in order to showcase the excellent work done by our photographer Michael Clevinger chronicling the construction of the Abraham Lincoln bridge in Louisville. While plenty of galleries existed detailing the manufacture of the bridge itself, the photos and audio here provide a human element by focusing on the individual laborers.

title: Public Defenders
description: This is a map of regions in Kentucky where public defenders work. Clicking on a region shows how in most cases their workload is way over the maximum threshold of recommended cases.

title: Structurally Deficient Bridge Map
description: A locator map of structurally deficient bridges in Louisville and the ratings assigned to them.

title: Flappy Card
description: In 2014 the game Flappy Bird for mobile platforms made headlines for deceptively simple yet addictive gameplay and the meteoric rise to fame of it's developer. We attempted to do something fun over the holiday season by creating a clone with UofL's mascot.

title: Tree Canopy Map
description: A map using the downtown tree canopy with a hotspot overlay.

title: Malt Madness Contest
description: Malt Madness was a fun little project that pitted Kentuckiana breweries against each other in a NCAA tournament style bracket competition. This was a sponsored product that generated revenue each year and coincided with a local event hosted by our spirits writer.
